meanings.definition: To remove a crown from someone's head.
meanings.sent1: The king decided to discrown himself and give the crown to his daughter.
meanings.sent2: The queen will discrown the prince if he does not fulfill his duties.
meanings.sent3: The jester tried to discrown the king as a prank, but it backfired hilariously.
meanings.sent4: The storm's fierce winds seemed to discrown the trees of their autumn leaves.
meanings.sent5: The magician's trick was to discrown the volunteer from the audience and then restore the crown in a flash of light.

meanings.definition: To deprive someone of royal or high status.
meanings.sent1: The scandal threatened to discrown the once-respected politician.
meanings.sent2: The jealous advisor plotted to discrown the beloved queen and take her place.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous fairy decided to discrown the arrogant prince to teach him a lesson.
meanings.sent4: The economic crisis seemed to discrown the wealthy businessman overnight.
meanings.sent5: The unexpected defeat in the tournament would discrown the reigning champion and shock the spectators.

meanings.definition: To dethrone or depose a monarch.
meanings.sent1: The rebels planned to discrown the tyrannical king and establish a new government.
meanings.sent2: The historical records show how rival factions would often discrown rulers to seize power.
meanings.sent3: The magical curse was said to discrown any ruler who dared to enter the forbidden chamber.
meanings.sent4: The prophecy foretold that a hero would rise to discrown the corrupt monarch and bring peace to the land.
meanings.sent5: The epic tale recounts the quest to discrown the immortal king and break the cycle of tyranny.
